Gloomy, Energetic and Drunk: York's Venues of Vitality

04/10/2022

Charis Horsley catches up with some local and university bands to discuss York's more intimate venues

Image by JL Media

By Charis Horsley

With York city resting on the smaller side, at first glance there are only a handful of venues to visit on a night out. Investigating the less well-known pockets of musical potential in York, suddenly a wealth of sound emerges. Iâ€™ve had the pleasure of interviewing three local bands in York: Slop â€˜Em Up, Whereâ€™s Slater and Everything After Midnight, as well as novice DJ, Krutika Gopalan. Speaking to these musical group members has provided a much closer look into what it is to thrive as a local or university band in York, really highlighting the more intimate and niche elements to underground sounds in the city. Forget the cheesy primary colours of Popworld and Flares, and open your eyes to the richer rock and bitter melodies of the underground.

The Fulford Arms, a popular gig location, has proven to be a common denominator across all of the bands. A small pub squatting in the middle of Fulford Road, just down from York Cemetery, the venue provides a simultaneous hub of country pub and roaring musical vitality. As a frequented venue, the Arms witnesses an array of sound, from nationwide names to upstartingÂ collectives. All three of the bands interviewed commented on their experiences playing in The Fulford Arms, with Everything After Midnight and Whereâ€™s Slater pinpointing it as their current favourite venue in York. Starting out May 2019, Everything After Midnight played at the Battle of the Bands final in 2020, their first gig at The Fulford Arms, â€œa really important gig for us and one of the busiest gigs we had played to dateâ€. Since then theyâ€™ve progressed immensely, supporting the SHEAFS (Sheffield rock band, new single described as â€œan adrenaline shot of sharp- eyed punkâ€), The Lounge Society and Marnie Glum. Everything After Midnight commented that â€œthe experience has always been really positive, the sound techs there are amazing and the staff always make us feel really welcome. Weâ€™ve got more gigs planned there and canâ€™t wait to be back on the stageâ€.

The experience at The Fulford Arms is singularly intimate, something disembodied from your average venue, such as the Barbican off from Paragon Street. The smaller space creates an electric atmosphere of communication between the crowd and the artist, allowing a dynamism of sound with both parties sharing the same space. Sound and lighting are well executed and vibrant, with the walls decorated with scrawled band names of those who have played. Whereâ€™s Slater expressed their pleasure at seeing their logo on the wall every time they visit. This collective space only enhances the exploit, by bringing together bands through the welcoming environment and shared experience of music.

Other locations frequented include The York Vaults, just off Nunnery Lane in the City Centre, a completely independent venue dedicated to providing a platform for new and upcoming musical artists, in support of Yorkâ€™s vibrant and diverse music scene. In answer to where their favourite venue was, Everything After Midnight commented, â€œwe always joke about the fact that we go through phases as a band - playing at one venue over and over again for a few months, and then we move on to the next one! Around the time of our EP release this was The York Vaults - we had some really big gigs there (our EP launch, supporting Do Nothing on their UK tour) and we felt very much at home on the stageâ€. Equally Slop â€˜Em Up expressed their pleasure of playing at the Crescent and the Vaults as their favourite venues, commenting, â€œtheyâ€™ve always treated us very nicely. The Vaults has a real intimate feel. 150 people feels like 500 in that sweet sweat boxâ€.

This intimacy is something DJ Krutika reiterates. Her alternative sound invites a wealth of venues slightly different to those of the local bands. Instead of The Fulford Arms, the Micklegate Social is a venue often played at by Krutika, yet she echoes the effectiveness of intimate and smaller venues. â€œMore intimate venues such as the Micklegate Social and Bluebox create spaces, although different, more meaningful for club goers. People in clubs want to meet people and lose themselves for a little bit - ironically I think a large club space defeats the purpose of thisâ€. The Micklegate Social is located just inside the city wall off from Micklegate, a small bar with an un- derground space embracing a variety of events. She adds, â€œsmaller club spaces are my personal favourite because they remind me of flat parties back in first year, with way too many crammedÂ into a grimy little kitchen â€“ a first â€œclubbingâ€ experience for many!â€ An experience for many students which came as a package deal with the Covid-19 lockdown, the limited social spaces ironically creating greater intimacy within the smaller venues.

Alongside these popular venues, there are other more niche venues to enjoy good music in York. Jazz inhabits spaces such as The Phoenix Pub, The Eagle and Child, the Crescent as well as Vanburgh Jazz night. These live music nights are particularly prominent for a more relaxed evening scene. The Phoenix sports a gem of dark wooden panelling and dim lighting illuminating the experience and making you feel as though you have just strolled into the 1930s.

I asked each of the local bands what they thought made York in particular a place for new bands to thrive. The most prominent answer was the cityâ€™s proximity and ease of access to many other bigger cities well-known for their music scenes such as Manchester, Leeds and Sheffield. Yet York being smaller itself provides advantages, â€œbeing such a small city, York definitely has a greatÂ community feel - whereas cities like Leeds and Manchester have loads of venues and promoters; everything in York is much smaller and itâ€™s much easier to find your feet. The venues and promoters really want small artists to thrive, I think thatâ€™s quite a rare thing in this day and ageâ€, comments Everything After Midnight, a view echoing The York Vaultâ€™s identity as a support for upcoming musical artists.

The Battle of the Bands, an annual campus event hosted jointly with the various media and music-related societies on campus, was mentioned by multiple bands as the best way to progress as an upstarting university band. To read further on the Battle of the Bands, check out Kristina Wemyssâ€™ article, â€˜Battle of the Bands 2021â€™. Advice from Whereâ€™s Slater also included joining the University of York Band Society as â€œa great atmosphere for finding friends to go to gigs with and band membersâ€, mirrored advice from Slop â€˜Em Up, advising musically inclined people to â€œloiter around BandSoc events, youâ€™ll usually catch some cool people playing thereâ€. Alternatively, Jacob from Everything After Midnight commented on both the importance and ease of just getting involved. â€œItâ€™s no exaggeration to sayÂ that thereâ€™s something on every night of the week in York - whether itâ€™s an open mic night, a gig, a festival in the street or a band playing an acoustic gig on a boat (yes this is happening in York - check out the Artsbarge). Both the event organisers and the artists are working really hard to put on events like this and really need the support.â€

The majority will understand the experience of watching a live performance from the position of the audience at a gig, jostled in the crowds and sweating from exhilaration, lyrics echoing from mouths all around. Yet, what is it like to be on the other side? Despite the obvious split, live performance involves lots of communication, with every band I interviewed emphasising that types of audience really matter. â€œAudiences 110% make a difference. one of the biggest parts of live music is the audience interaction, and if youâ€™ve got a nice crowd it makes the gig so much betterâ€, commented Whereâ€™s Slater. Everything After Midnight shared, â€œlast year we released a track called â€˜Embark On The Woodâ€™ - the audience participation with the backing â€˜Woah-oh-a-ohâ€™sâ€™ have become something of a staple in our live set - itâ€™s always fun to hear people singing them back to you!â€. This group of local bands also have a wide proportion of a shared fanbase, making gigs a supportive experience when they play together, â€œweâ€™re able to hype the crowds up for each otherâ€™s performancesâ€. The crowd for university bands such as Slop â€˜Em Up attracts a student based crowd, â€œwe usually play for our friends but itâ€™s always cool to see people rock up who none of us know. Generally we get fun-loving crowds of studentsâ€.

Pinning down each groupâ€™s sound in three words, Slop â€˜Em Up advocates for â€œB-side bang- ers onlyâ€, where Everything After Midnight comically identifies as â€œNot Wolf Aliceâ€. But Krutika and Whereâ€™s Slater really encapsulate the genre of the more intimate musical scene I want to capture, with the DJ sets being, â€œenergetic, atmospheric and personalâ€ and the band, â€œgloomy, energetic and drunkâ€. This culture of upcoming music is immersed in inclusivity, intimacy and imagination, things really lacking from many mainstream events. York provides a synthesis of music and venues suited to supporting upcoming artists, and bands, which is certainly something useful for university students interested Yorkâ€™s more niche music scene.
